text: Introduction: The present study investigated the relationship between beta-amyloid (Ab) and cognition in a late middle-aged cohort at risk for Alzheimer's disease (AD). Methods: One eighty-four participants (mean age 5 60; 72% parental history of AD) completed a [C-11]Pittsburgh compound B positron emission tomography scan and serial cognitive evaluations. A global measure of Ab burden was calculated, and composite scores assessing learning, delayed memory, and executive functioning were computed. Results: Higher Ab was associated with classification of psychometric mild cognitive impairment (MCI) at follow-up (P , .01). Linear mixed effects regression results indicated higher Ab was associated with greater rates of decline in delayed memory (P ,.01) and executive functioning (P ,.05). Apolipoprotein E (APOE) ε4 status moderated the relationship between Ab and cognitive trajectories (P values ,.01).

Beta-amyloid (Ab) deposition is hypothesized to occur early in the development of Alzheimer's disease (AD), possibly 15-20 years before a dementia diagnosis [1, 2] . The reported relationship between Ab and cognition measured at a single assessment in cognitively healthy individuals has been inconsistent, with some studies reporting modest associations [3] [4] [5] [6] [7] [8] and others demonstrating no significant relationship [9] [10] [11] [12] . However, longitudinal studies examining a variety of cognitive domains and ranging from 6-month to 10-year intervals more consistently reveal negative relationships between Ab and cognition [13] [14] [15] [16] [17] [18] [19] [20] [21] . Moreover, genetic risk for AD (possession of the apolipoprotein E ε4 [APOE ε4] allele) may moderate this relationship [22] [23] [24] [25] .
Most studies have focused on the relationship between Ab, APOE, and cognition in older adults (e.g., .65 years) at risk for AD with fewer investigations in middle age (e.g., 45-65 years). Because Ab is hypothesized to accumulate early and then plateau [1, 26] , it may be possible to detect a subtle, yet clinically meaningful, relationship between Ab and cognitive decline in midlife while Ab is accumulating and cognition begins declining. Higher Ab in middle age may also provide earlier prediction of disease progression. The objective of this study was to examine whether Ab is associated with longitudinal cognitive change in a late middle-aged cohort enriched for parental history of AD (Wisconsin Registry for Alzheimer's Prevention [WRAP] ). The first aim investigated whether Ab is associated with classification of psychometric mild cognitive impairment (MCI) at recent follow-up. The second aim was to determine whether Ab is associated with longitudinal cognitive trajectories. The third aim explored whether APOE ε4 moderates the relationship between Ab and cognitive trajectories. We hypothesized that higher Ab would be associated with increased MCI and greater cognitive decline, and that the association between Ab and cognitive decline would be strongest in APOE ε4 carriers.

Participants were selected from the WRAP, a late middleaged, cognitively healthy longitudinal cohort (mean age 5 53.6 years, standard deviation [SD] 5 6.6, at baseline) enriched for AD risk factors of APOE ε4 carrier status (40%) and parental history of AD (72%) [27] . The WRAP protocol includes a baseline neuropsychological evaluation (wave 1), a second visit four years after baseline (wave 2), and subsequent visits every two years (waves [3] [4] . Because a subset of neuropsychological measures was not initiated until wave 2, the present study design included data collected at waves 2, 3, and 4, excluding wave 1. Participants in the current sample (n 5 184) also completed a neuroimaging procedure. The number of participants whose last visit was wave 2, 3, or 4 was 6 (3%), 53 (29%), and 125 (68%), respectively. Of the 59 participants who had not completed wave 4, only 2 (1%) were no longer enrolled in WRAP (1 due to dementia diagnosis, 1 deceased), and 57 remained enrolled but had not yet returned for follow-up because of the staggered enrollment of participants. The University of Wisconsin Institutional Review Board approved all study procedures, and each participant provided signed informed consent before participation.

section_title: Magnetic resonance imaging and positron emission tomography acquisition
text:
All participants completed a 70-minute dynamic [C-11] Pittsburgh compound B (PiB) positron emission tomography (PET) scan on a Siemens EXACT HR1 scanner and a T1-weighted anatomic scan on a GE 3.0 T MR750 (Waukesha, WI, USA) using an 8-channel head coil, typically acquired on the same day. The neuroimaging procedure was completed on average 1.4 years (SD 5 1.4) after the wave 2 WRAP visit. Anatomic scans were reviewed by a neuroradiologist (H.A.R.) for exclusionary abnormalities. Detailed methods for [C-11]PiB radiochemical synthesis, PiB-PET scanning, and distribution volume ratio (DVR) map generation have been described previously [12, 28] . Briefly, the reconstructed PET data time series were motion corrected, denoised, and coregistered to the T1-weighted anatomic scan, and data were transformed into voxelwise DVR images representing [C-11]PiB binding using the time activity from the cerebellum gray matter as a reference function.
Eight bilateral AD-sensitive regions-of-interest (ROIs; angular gyrus, anterior cingulate gyrus, posterior cingulate gyrus, frontal medial orbital gyrus, precuneus, supramarginal gyrus, middle temporal gyrus, and superior temporal gyrus) were selected from the automated anatomic labeling atlas and were standardized and reverse warped to native space. A composite measurement of global amyloid was calculated [29] and used as the measure of Ab.

Cognitive composite scores were used to reduce measurement error and potential type I error associated with conducting multiple comparisons. Three composite scores for each of waves 2-4 were calculated by transforming raw scores to z-scores using the means and SDs of the current sample at each wave and averaging the z-scores for the three measures (listed below) included in each composite score.

section_title: Classification of MCI and cognitively normal
text: Participants were classified as cognitively normal (CN) or psychometric MCI (pMCI) based on neuropsychological performances at their most recent WRAP visit (mean (SD) 5 1.7 (0.8) years after PiB-PET scan). The pMCI criterion was developed to identify participants with very mild impairment who may progress to a clinical diagnosis of MCI. Specifically, participants were classified as having pMCI if performances on at least two individual tests within a cognitive domain (learning, delayed recall, executive functioning) or one test in each of the three cognitive domains were at least 1.5 SDs below the mean of an internally derived robust normative sample [37, 38] . The robust normative sample included 476 WRAP participants that remained cognitively normal throughout the duration of the study.
All statistical analyses were conducted in SPSS version 22. Statistical significance was defined as P , .05 unless specified otherwise.

section_title: Relationship between Ab and follow-up cognitive status
text: A logistic regression analysis examined if Ab predicted follow-up cognitive status at most recent visit (CN vs. pMCI), controlling for covariates of age at PiB-PET scan, sex, literacy, number of years enrolled in WRAP, and interval (years) between PiB-PET scan and most recent neuropsychological evaluation.

section_title: Relationship among Ab and longitudinal cognitive trajectories
text: Linear mixed effects regression allows modeling of fixed effects (e.g., overall patterns on cognitive measures across visits) while accounting for random effects (e.g., variation associated with individual differences) and may detect decline on cognitive measures that does not exceed a specific clinical cutoff. Analyses were conducted with each cognitive composite score (learning, delayed recall, executive functioning) as an outcome variable. First, unconditional means and growth models adjusting for random effects of intercept and slope were examined for each of two covariance-variance structures (uncorrelated intercept and slope ["variance components"] and correlation permitted between intercept and slope ["unstructured"]). The final covariance-variance structure was selected based on model fit indices (Akaike information criterion). Subsequent conditional models included significant random effects plus fixed effects of sex, literacy, interval between wave 2 cognitive evaluation and PiB-PET scan (years), Ab (PiB DVR), time (age [centered] at each visit), and the interaction of time ! Ab. Time was operationalized as the age at each WRAP visit to provide more precise information about participants at each evaluation compared with a fixed time-structured variable. A Bonferroni correction was applied to correct for multiple comparisons (i.e., familywise alpha 5 0.05 was divided by 3; 0.05/3 5 0.017 significance level used for each outcome variable).

section_title: Relationships between Ab and longitudinal cognitive trajectories
text: Results from linear mixed effects regression models examining the relationships among Ab, time, and composite score at each visit are presented in Table 3 . A significant interaction between time and Ab indicated higher Ab was associated with increased rate of decline in delayed recall performance, F(1,309.33) 5 9.42, B 5 20.14, P 5 .002 (Fig. 3, middle left) . The interaction between time and Ab for learning performance did not reach statistical significance, F(1,485.11) 5 3.82, B 5 20.08, P 5 .051 (Fig. 3,  top left) . A significant main effect of time indicated that as individuals progressed through the study, learning performance decreased, F(1,431.96) 5 11.18, B 5 20.02, P 5 .001. A smaller, though statistically significant effect was observed for the interaction between time and Ab for executive functioning, indicating higher Ab was associated with increased rate of decline in executive functioning performance, F(1,444.95) 5 5.87, B 5 20.09; P 5 .016 (Fig. 3, bottom left) .

Although AD pathology begins years before clinical symptoms emerge [39] and cognitive impairment develops several years before an MCI or dementia diagnosis [40] , the relationship between the earliest detectable pathology and cognitive change is not well understood. Prior longitudinal studies observed that older adults with greater Ab exhibited increased rates of cognitive decline [13] [14] [15] [16] [17] [18] [19] [20] [21] . The present study adds that higher Ab in midlife in those at risk for AD is associated with steeper cognitive decline resulting in a greater incidence of progression to pMCI.

Although Ab was not associated with cognitive status at the visit closest to the PiB-PET scan, higher Ab was associated with greater likelihood of pMCI classification at approximately 2-year follow-up. Although neuropsychological performance demonstrated stronger relationships with follow-up cognitive status (previously shown in [41] ), Ab remained as a significant contributor to the models, suggesting it may account for variance in follow-up cognitive status not explained by cognitive performance. These results are consistent with prior studies demonstrating greater rates of progression to MCI or dementia in participants with higher Ab. For example, one study observed that 16% of older controls with high Ab developed MCI or dementia within 2 years, and 25% progressed within 3 years [42] . The current sample is younger (mean age 5 60 years) than that described by Villemagne et al [42] (mean age 5 73 years) and suggests that higher Ab predicts progression to neuropsychological impairment that may precede a clinical MCI diagnosis. However, as the construct of pMCI represents a milder form of decline, it will be necessary to document whether these individuals progress to clinical diagnoses with continued follow-up.

section_title: High Ab is associated with cognitive decline
text:
Ab was associated with an increased rate of decline in delayed memory and executive functioning. Results indicated a stronger relationship between Ab and delayed memory decline compared with learning and executive functioning, consistent with prior findings [8] . Previous cross-sectional studies of Ab and cognition in the WRAP cohort have been mixed. For example, baseline cognitive performance did not differ between groups divided into Ab positive, Ab negative, and Ab indeterminate [12] . Additionally, no differences in precuneus amyloid load were observed between a "stable" and "decliner" group defined by RAVLT performance [41] . However, a recent cross-sectional study demonstrated greater age-related decline in processing speed among Ab-positive compared with Ab-negative participants, suggesting that "normal" changes in cognition that occur with aging may be accelerated in the presence of amyloid pathology [43] .
The present study differed from these prior studies in quantification of Ab (composite measure across eight ROIs examined continuously) and the longitudinal method of measuring cognition (mean slopes across 4 years). By examining mean slopes, while accounting for individual differences through inclusion of random effects, the current analysis attempted to detect meaningful change, even if cognitive performance fell within a cognitively normal range. For example, decline in cognitive performance associated with higher Ab remained within the normal range (declines from wz 5 0.5 to w z 5 20.5), and average performances on cognitive measures remained within normal limits at each visit. These results of subtle cognitive decline associated with Ab may be difficult to detect via traditional clinical methods and cross-sectional designs and are consistent with findings in longitudinal cohorts of older adults such as Baltimore Longitudinal Study of Aging [18] , Australian Imaging, Biomarkers, and Lifestyle study [20] , and the Harvard Aging Brain Study [17] . Our findings suggest that Ab-associated decline may be detected in younger ages than previously examined.

section_title: APOE ε4 moderates the relationship between Ab and cognitive decline
text:
Similar to prior studies, APOE ε4 carriers exhibited higher Ab than noncarriers [22, 44] . Furthermore, the presence of APOE ε4 moderated the association between Ab and cognitive decline. Although some studies reported null effects of APOE genotype on rates of decline [20, 45] , our results of a moderating effect of APOE are consistent with subsequent studies using larger sample sizes and longitudinal follow-up [22] [23] [24] . The current results were driven by a significant interaction between Ab and time within APOE ε4 carriers that was not observed within noncarriers. As displayed in Fig. 3 , the association between higher Ab and time on memory performance in ε4 carriers was negative and demonstrated the steepest rate of decline. An unexpected positive association was observed between lower Ab and time on memory performance in ε4 carriers. The latter result may be due to sampling bias, as ε4 carriers with low Ab were less prevalent and younger than other participants and included fewer participants that had yet to return for their fourth evaluation. However, results from a post hoc analysis suggested that varied number of observations did not fully account for differences between ε4 carriers with high or low Ab. It is possible that the sample size was too small to adequately investigate the interaction between Ab and APOE, and followup studies on larger samples are required to replicate these findings. Interestingly, a very recent study of older adults within the AIBL cohort similarly reported unexpected findings of improved memory performance in ε4 carriers with low Ab compared with noncarriers with low Ab [46] , which may warrant investigation of potential protective mechanisms in this group.
The mechanisms underlying the relationship between APOE ε4 and Ab are becoming increasingly understood (see [47] ). APOE ε4 carriers exhibit Ab approximately 20 years earlier than noncarriers (e.g., age 55 years compared with age 75 years). APOE ε4 may moderate cognitive decline and increase risk for AD by initiating and accelerating Ab accumulation, aggregation, and clearance in the brain. APOE ε4 carriers could also be more vulnerable to Ab-related toxicity because of Ab-independent effects on neuronal integrity [48] .

The present study used a global composite measure of Ab to summarize diffuse pathology in regions with reported increased PiB binding levels in AD; however, it is possible that regionally specific relationships between Ab and cognition are not captured. Furthermore, the PiB-PET scan was not acquired concurrently with the initial cognitive evaluation, complicating attempts to characterize the specific time course of Ab development and cognitive decline. Additionally, the present study did not examine potential effects of neurofibrillary tangle pathology, neurodegeneration, or cerebrovascular disease on cognitive decline. However, incorporation of both Ab and neuronal injury measures may provide the most accurate prognosis [49] , and this is a future direction. Moreover, the sample is enriched for AD risk and is a highly educated, mostly Caucasian sample from the Midwest region of the United States. These results may not generalize to population-based samples of normally aging middle-aged adults.
Despite these limitations, results suggest that Ab burden in late middle age is associated with cognitive decline over a 4-year period and predictive of pMCI diagnosis at follow-up in individuals at risk for AD. Furthermore, APOE ε4 carriers with greater Ab may decline faster than ε4 carriers with low Ab or noncarriers. These results suggest that identification of preclinical AD may be possible in cognitively healthy middle-aged adults with higher Ab who may benefit most from clinical trials attempting to slow the rate of cognitive decline before the onset of clinical symptoms of MCI or dementia.

1. Systematic review: A literature review was conducted using PubMed and Web of Science databases to identify studies of beta-amyloid, [C-11]Pittsburgh compound B positron emission tomography, apolipoprotein E (APOE) genotype, and cognition. Although cross-sectional studies were mixed, longitudinal studies described consistent associations between greater beta-amyloid and memory decline. Most studies focused on elderly samples, with few on middle-aged individuals.
2. Interpretation: This study contributes to the literature by demonstrating that higher beta-amyloid is associated with steeper decline in delayed recall and executive functioning in a middle-aged cohort at risk for Alzheimer's disease, resulting in greater progression to mild cognitive impairment. This relationship was strongest in APOE ε4 carriers.
3. Future directions: Research questions generated include further exploration of (1) distinct effects of beta-amyloid on cognition within APOE ε4 carriers; (2) cognitive decline on neuropsychological measures comprising composites and associated with beta-amyloid in particular brain regions; and (3) potential moderating effects of neurofibrillary tangle pathology, neurodegeneration, and cerebrovascular disease on cognition in middle age.
